S. H.

WHY DID WESTERN CANADIANS IMMIGRATE?

A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Board, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: John W. Thomas
Address: Tuxford, Sask.
Birthplace: Ontario

1. INTRODUCTION TO IMMIGRATION

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1906
Where did you set up housekeeping? TUXFORD, SASK.
Where had you been living before that? A.A.B.F.T.H., ONT.
For how many people did you prepare meals? 1—10
How far was it to your nearest store? 1/4 MILE, E.S.WEST, 1 1/2 MILES
How often could a visit be made to the store? ONCE PER WEEK
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? TEA, FLOUR, SUGAR, DRIED FRUITS, CANNED GOODS.

After 1906 I lived alone 45 miles from Swift Current at TYNER, SASK. Then in 1910 I was married & took up residence at TUXFORD 1/2 miles from Village.

14. **Shopping and Containers**

   Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible). Monthly everything was in bulk in 1906.

15. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

   *Family of 4 and half 1 man and missionary*

   Breakfast: Porridge, meat, potatoes, bread or toast + fruit or syrup tea or coffee children took milk

   Dinner: Potatoes, one other vegetable, meat pie or pudding, pickles tea milk for children bread

   Supper: Potatoes, meat, bread, often few cakes in winter with syrup, or pie cake or fruit tea milk for children

16. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Eastern Canada? 1910

   Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at that time.

   Turkey, vegetables, mince pie and plum pudding

   There were five present all adults.

17. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

   Only for very brief periods before I was married on home stead, when we couldn't make trip over had only corn syrup and oat meal 3 days and short on flour about week no meat for 3 days then a Jack Rabbit which I shot near barn I had no pigs or chickens or cow then 4th day rode to store 6 miles got some flour, corned milk and salmon this did for about 2 weeks with Jack rabbit then more rabbits came in was very short of wood too.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of home grown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

we had come from Ontario was used to farming
and liked to garden we grew many vegetables
and flowers for the first time they were grown
in our district some were failures due to wrong
varieties tried and methods used now we
grow nearly everything on our farm 1/2 miles
from Tuford known as TALBOT FARM.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. [Use back of page if more space is needed].

Lack of cash made it necessary to buy
much stuff on time for which we paid
terrible rates of interest but our TUXFORD
farm 1 section now was especially good
land we formed it well under any and
every condition of poor prices or better so
we usually had a crop. We worked very
hard but were very healthy and very happy.
We do not farm now but visit the farms each
Lack of cash made it necessary to buy much stuff on time for which we paid terrible rates of interest but our Tuxford farm location was especially good land we farmed it well under my and every condition of poor prices or better so we usually had a crop we worked very hard but were very healthy and very happy.

we do not farm now but visit the farms each own
Summer for about 6 months and live in Calgary for the other 6 months because of my health. I developed asthma in 1935 and can live easier in the cold months here.

We consider a good farm well-formed still the best place for young people to start, and to raise a family but work will always be necessary along with careful planning on any farm even with modern methods.

John W Thomas
age 67
TUXFORD
SASK
